div.head: Abstract
div.p: This study focuses on performing arts in the search of the new insights that may be brought from identity as critical perspective. To achieve this purpose, the research challenges dialectics and crosses disciplines with the aim of revealing how performance concerns the being, the subject, the person and the citizen.

If the first chapter introduces the research design and its critical methods, the second covers the theoretical framework: the field of study and the analytic categories. From its emergence at the end of 19th Century until the performative turn of the mid-20th, socio‑cultural boundaries are discussed questioning the autonomy of the field. About identity, a cartography of the term is sketched setting out the viewpoints that guide the furtherance of the thesis.

The third chapter formulates research’s own conceptual core by means of building its paradigmatic object: the performative device. Interplays between technological disposition and subjectivizing power extend the understanding of theatrical practices as communicative mediated interactions. The analysis of bodyness and space‑time concomitance is also related with the ontological and gnoseological dynamics brought by the performative
apparatus .

The fourth chapters focuses on poetics as a bridge to the practice. The creative process and its outcome, the discourse on stage, are inquired on their independence to observe the limits of the individualist auctoritas . The imaginary roots inside the psyche and the discursive pragmatics into the socio‑cultural milieu are examined to scrutinize the thresholds of subjective creativity.

To summarize, the study highlights some of the outputs brought by trespassing the identity/difference dialectic, specifically those concerning transduction and transhumanity in terms of the medium and of the agency respectively. Performance arises as a dazzling subject for critical philosophy as it unveils a meaningful ambit of interaction among theatre and power‑knowledge for analysis. Applied consequences are draft for further development on artistic production, theatre education and therapy.

div.head: Resumen
div.p: Este estudio se centra en las artes escénicas en la búsqueda de los nuevos aportes que pueden revelarse desde la perspectiva crítica de la identidad. Para conseguir su propósito, la investigación desafía a la metodología dialéctica y atraviesa disciplinas con el objetivo de descubrir cómo la performance concierne al ser, al sujeto, a la persona y al ciudadano.

Si el primer capítulo presenta el diseño de investigación, el segundo se encarga del marco teórico: el campo de estudio y las categorías analíticas. Con respecto al campo, desde su emergencia a finales del siglo XIX hasta el giro performativo a mediados del XX, las fronteras socioculturales que lo delimitan son discutidas cuestionando su autonomía. Con respecto a la identidad, se esboza una cartografía del término estableciendo los puntos de vista que guían el ulterior desarrollo de la tesis.

El tercer capítulo desarrolla el núcleo conceptual de la investigación a través de la construcción de su objeto paradigmático: el dispositivo escénico/teatral. Los vínculos entre la disposición tecnológica y el poder subjetivador extienden la comprensión de las prácticas teatrales como mediaciones comunicativas. El análisis de la interfaz performática se centra en las relaciones entre la corporalidad espacio‑temporal y la dinámisis gnoseo‑ontológica.

El cuarto capítulo se ocupa de la poética como puente hacia la práctica. Cuestionándose los límites de la auctoritas individual, el proceso creativo es investigado en busca del grado de autonomía de su resultado, el discurso escénico. Asimismo, la acción imaginaria y la pragmática discursiva son analizadas para discutir los límites psico‑sociales de la subjetividad creativa.

Como conclusión, el estudio destaca los resultados obtenidos por medio de la superación de la dialéctica identidad/diferencia, especialmente aquellos relacionados con la mediación (transducción) y la agencia (transhumanidad). Lo performativo deslumbra como tema para la filosofía crítica en cuanto posibilita un ámbito significativo y renovador para el análisis del poder/conocimiento. Para finalizar se apuntan algunas directrices que pueden guiar la práctica teatral en el ámbito de la producción, la educación y la terapia.

div.head: Introducción

epigraph.quote: We are, as we behave. As we do, we become.

div.p: This dissertation is driven to explore the identities of the creation, the creation of identities and the interactions among both extents. This overall purpose specifically observes the subject in terms of artistic practice girding the ambit of investigation to the understanding of the processes by which performance concerns identity and viceversa.

div.head: Preguntas de investigación

list.item: ¿Qué tipo de relaciones podemos establecer entre las artes escénicas y los procesos identitarios?
¿Qué nuevos insights puede ofrecernos el estudio de este objeto relacional?
¿Qué nuevas orientaciones prácticas pueden surgir tanto en creación, educación y terapia de estas consideraciones críticas escénico‑identitarias?
¿Cómo determinar los métodos de una investigación transdisciplinar, constructivista y orientada a la práctica?

div.p: Estas preguntas tienen implícitas otras de segundo orden pero que ayudan a entender el ámbito de investigación y su aproximación.

list.item: ¿En qué consiste la identidad? ¿A qué nos referimos cuando decimos la identidad como perspectiva crítica?
¿Cómo definir nuestro campo en el sentido bourdieuano? ¿Podemos establecer en él una confluencia para los paradigmas de la teatralidad y la performance?

div.head: Hipótesis
div.p: Partimos de una única hipótesis central que podemos formular del siguiente modo:

p.emph: Redefinir el campo de las artes escénicas a partir del paradigma crítico de la identidad puede ofrecer nuevas perspectivas y nuevos conocimientos acerca tanto de las artes performáticas como de la propia cuestión identitaria.

div.head: Estado de la cuestión
div.p: Nos enfrentamos al estudio de un objeto relacional y por este motivo resulta más evidente que es la investigación la que construye su propio objeto y no a la inversa. Las categorías que estructuran el ámbito de la práctica no tienen que ser necesariamente las que mejor sirvan para estructurar el ámbito del análisis ni tampoco la aplicación de las categorías utilizadas en el análisis tiene por qué ser el mejor camino para la orientación de las prácticasVer a continuación (§) la crítica de la proyección del concepto de identidad de la práctica al análisis social a partir del artículo Beyond Identity (Brubaker & Cooper, 2000) .

Si bien la identidad no es un parámetro primario en la articulación de las prácticas escénico/teatrales y por lo tanto no definitorio en la demarcación del campo en cuanto no supone un espacio de tensión para los agentes del modo que lo es la cuestión de la auctoritas. Existen no obstante algunas excepciones en la práctica escénico/teatral en las que la cuestión identitaria dinamiza explícitamente las prácticas, pero mencionarlas nos sirve para enfatizar la diferencia que pretendemos establecer entre analizar las prácticas escénico/teatrales en las que la identidad es una cuestión prioritaria y analizar ya no unas prácticas concretas sino el campo en su totalidad en términos identitarios. Por no eludir las excepciones, trataremos de organizarlas en tres grupos y, mencionando algún caso paradigmático, evitaremos entrar en listados siempre parciales e inconclusos. En primer lugar debemos mencionar el movimiento Teatro x la identidad –movimiento de profesionales de las artes escénicas comprometidos con la identificación de los bebés robados bajo el amparo del régimen militar en Argentina– y en segundo lugar la poética de introspección subjetiva

div.head: Objetivos
div.p: El objetivo principal es acceder al sentido de las prácticas escénico/teatrales desde una nueva perspectiva que nos permita trascender una comprensión dialéctica, es decir que evite la división de los fenómenos a partir de categorías binarias enfrentadas. La dialéctica ha dinamizado la modernidad, su epistemología (racionalismo - empirismo), la estética (realismo - idealismo), la metafísica (cuerpo - alma), la sociología (individuo - colectividad, agencia - estructura), la lingüística (significante - significado), la economía (oferta - demanda)… En lo concerniente a la identidad, igualmente, la principal aproximación ontológica mana de su oposición con la diferencia, de la dicotomía entre ipseidad y alteridad. Desde una perspectiva política, la ciudadanía y el sistema de derechos define sus límites a partir de un exterior constitutivo, el alienus , y los movimientos sociales articulan sus demandas en términos de hegemonía y subalternidad.

Esta investigación en primer lugar se propone una primera aproximación al campo escénico/teatral en términos bourdieuanos. En segundo lugar se propone crear en torno a la identidad un rango de análisis transdisciplinar a partir del cual redefinir el campo escénico/teatral. Decimos redefinir porque la investigación se propone la construcción de un objeto que pueda surgir de las categorías identitarias en la clasificación de sus límites. Podemos sintetizar diciendo que pretendemos comprobar si se puede hablar de una identidad propia de las prácticas escénicas así como de una escena identitaria.
Esta definición compete en primer lugar a un ámbito teórico, en el que abordar los aspectos epistemológicos y ontológicos, en segundo lugar a un ámbito empírico, en el que abordar las cuestiones poéticas, éticas y estéticas, y en tercer lugar a un ámbito práctico, donde abordar la creación y la didáctica desde los fundamentos anteriores.

div.head: Metodología
div.p: Los métodos de la investigación surgen de una no siempre explícita determinación epistemológica. En nuestro caso, la investigación se concibe desde un posicionamiento constructivista según el cual es la investación la que concibe su objeto y no al contrario, lo que obliga a buscar un método no dialéctico que pueda ofrecer una alternativa a la estructura tesis, antítesis, sintesis (Propper, 1962).

div.head: Performing Arts as a field of study
div.p: As we can distinct an ambit for social practice that involves ritualized human body expressiveness we may define a field whose core is linguistic independent and that includes the endowments of the artistic communicative human presence, which is moreover diverse and ubiquitous in human societies.

The field is referred in different manners, as is normally the case. If Live arts is used, Performing Arts is widely accepted in the Anglo-Saxon domains. In francophone realms
Spectacle vivant is most common, and Artes Escénicas -Artes Cênicas is prevalent in Spanish - Português. Sometimes it is just referred as Theatre. Regardless of the name, different aspects of the field are highlighted in every expression and therefore all of them are useful to define its boundaries in different circumstances There is a preference in this work for the term Performing Arts to refer to the field, but synonyms are adopted as well. The main reason for the preference lays on the strong dependence the research holds on constructivist epistemology, and the verb to perform —that etymologically we may define as to provide a form— refers to the constructive capacities of the action to become discourse.. Accentuation both on the organic nature of the expression and on its presence, hence on bodyness, is given in allusion to theliving condition of the phenomenon, in contrast to other expressive practices that involve registration. Spectacle, from Latin spectaculum , refers to exposition to public view and connotes the duration, the show time, in contrast with theatre, from Greek θέατρον, that denotes sometimes the place for seeing others the spectators. Complementary, scene, from Greek σκηνή, comes to allude to the stage or the architecture addressed to the play. Whereas performance focuses on the action that is running.

Our field includes communicative practices artistically codified in which humans come together and coexist either performing or sensing. But referring a field in the conception of Bourdieu requires a more detailed prospect for the structure of the domain. The emergence of a field is not only mater of pratiques, but also of agents, whose stances invigorate the beat of the field. We consider Performing Arts to be a research field as long as it exists a public accredited ecosystem of practitioners —artists, technicians, producers, curators, managers, critics, scholars, scientists, politicians, pedagogues, students, enthusiasts and, of course, devoted and audiences— embodying their values, staking their objectives on the playground: agents who are mutual recognized, who play and create the rules that confine the field —rules that are dynamic discourses and can be discursively criticized—, who constant refer back to a common history and who share a common illusio. Furthermore, fields are also ruled by a dramatic logic as far as agents dispose and constest for different capitals not only economic but also symbolic Bourdieu [1976] 2002.

The remark in a revolutionary confrontation meets the emphatic Bourdieu’s notion of field as arena within agents struggle for their positions. One among the critics on such confronting conception points to the limits it holds for the understanding of cooperative relations inside fields. The particular situation in our case, cooperative alliances between artists across disciplines was a prominent aspect for the emergence of an inclusive scene capable of merging different languages for attaining artistic recognition. Nevertheless, understanding fields as confronting spaces makes historical dynamics possible. The new born modern theatre first acquired a dualistic structure in result of the polarization of the market between the the wide audience oriented and the avant-garde productions. Audience as symbolic capital is crucial in the struggle between the mainstream and the off theatre not only for economic reasons but for a complex amalgam of interests that can be summarized as power/knowledge. The battle for their positions in the field, for the hegemony of their discourses, is what makes agents into subjects of changes rather than into certain result of the structuring capabilities of field’s dispositionis. This is the vision of reality that enables critical paradigm. Not forgetting to mention audience per se as the most determining agent in the field as far as no audience, no show.

The bourdieuian notion of field, which is by the way based on the foundations of modern social sciences since Durkheim,Marx and Weber —the symbolic nature of the relational dynamics that settle human societies—, enables the critical paradigm bypassing the limits of an historical perspective only observant of aesthetic (internal properties) throwing light into the network of relations as into the struggles for dominating positions (politics).

Concerning artistic production, the art of stage emerges as an autonomous region during the period from the last quarter of the Nineteenth Century to the Second World War. This demarcation does not deny the importance of the vanguards of the second half of the Twentieth Century neither the social and cultural shake after May of 1968, but a first hypothesis is implied advocating that the trends we aim to track concerning performance were already traced before 1939. Far from the intention of treating an erudite collection of the forms —as if they weren’t living forms and so self accomplished and only attainable through primary even secondary discourses about the forms— a genealogy is sketched with the aim of clearing the way for criticism. Even the systemic conception of field itself must be criticized in their possibilities and limitations. History is summoned to detail the breaking points whose effects had led the dynamism of the forces. Hence, so many names may be felt missed. This disclaimer is to be considered for the study of a systemic social domain not for the systematic review of a series of tokens previously reified by scientific discourses about the field. With the hope of introducing the research in a very wide shot, tensions among forces concerning aesthetics, politics and metaphysics are outlined.

div.head: Genealogy

sp.speaker: STAGE-DIRECTOR
sp.p: A play is a work of literature, is it not? Tell me, then, how one art can possibly be another?

sp.speaker: PLAYGOER
sp.p: Well, then, if you tell me that the Art of the Theatre is neither the acting nor the play, then I must come to the conclusion that it is the scenery and the dancing. Yet I cannot think you will tell me this is so.

sp.speaker: STAGE-DIRECTOR
sp.p: No; the Art of the Theatre is neither acting nor the play, it is not scene nor dance, but it consists of all the elements of which these things are composed: action, which is the very spirit of acting; words, which are the body of the play; line and colour, which are the very heart of the scene; rhythm, which is the very essence of dance.

sp.speaker: PLAYGOER
sp.p: Action, words, line, colour, rhythm! And which of these is all-important to the art?

sp.speaker: STAGE-DIRECTOR
sp.p: One is no more important than the other, no more than one colour is more important to a painter than another, or one note more important than another to a musician. In one respect, perhaps, action is the most valuable part. Action bears the same relation to the Art of the Theatre as drawing does to painting, and melody does to music. The Art of the Theatre has sprung from action movement dance.

div.p: Arts and crafts empowered the emergence of the european modern scene and this aspect will be prevalent in the nature of the field either or not practices taking place inside the architectonic confines of roofed-in theaters. Every performative practice, either conventional or innovative, from the more complex opera to the minimum performative event, requires both specific arts related with the articulation of the extent that will be co-inhabited by performers and audience, and specific social terms for the event to be accepted as a public communicative concurrence. Agents claiming for recognition were those actualizing techniques remained valid since the eighteenth century both scenic (italianate dispositio of stage and auditorium, lighting procedures, painted backdrops and, maybe with more prevalence, acting schemes) as productive (production budgets, season proceeds, tournées, troupe and repertory management, communicative strategies…) Techniques were improved for better accomplishing entertainment but, at the same time, they were enabling further revolutionary positions at least for poetics, as those from Erwin Piscator, that make use of the theatrical instrumentum although trying to achieve other non-mercantile objectives.

cit.quote: No es ninguna casualidad que en una época en la que los lógros técnicos sobresalen como una torre por encima de los otros se produzca una tecnificación de la escena. Y mucho menos casual resulta el que esta tecnificación haya recibido un impulso precisamente de un sector que se encuentra en contradición con el orden social. Las revoluciones espirituales y sociales siempre han estado estrechamente ligadas a transformaciones técnicas. Tampoco el cambio de función del teatro era pensable sin una nueva configuración técnica del aparato escénico.

div.p: But if staging is matter of craftsmanship, theatricality is about protocol and requires a public contract with society about the rules of the showing. The rules of the showing are external to the logic of discourse (the rules of the show) and concern the etiquette and the legal framework. Bourgeois manners consist of entertainment: what is performed in scene is framed out from reality through the proscenium arch. Known to have its first model in Teatre Farnese —inserted in Parma in 1619 by Giovanni Battista Aleotti (Tidworth, 1973, pp. 65-68)—, Italian architecture is conceived for auditors to feel though they were placed in the scene themselves. Perspective enables the existence of the illusio as a reality for the senses. Each spectator becomes an isolated individual who enjoys the rights to see, hear and remain silent. The world of the audience simply blacks out and disappear, at least for those siting in the ground flour. Those on balconies can expect others expecting. It is not in vain that baroque buildings were heir of feudal aristocracy. One among the modernizing forces that emerged in the field were related with the collective conception of society that came up against distinctions accepted in class societies. Italian dispositio was rejected outright in pro of the audience to feel as collective and the event to be perceived as communion. One among the pioneer renovating architectures following this plan was the Münchener Künstler-Theater, first opened in 1908 and directed by Georg Fuchs. The venue was built to reinforce audience implication as inheritance of original Hellenistic rites. Arquitecture disregards baroque dispositio including palchi and proscenium.

div.p: Reaction against habits of entertainment involving individualism, psychology and subjectivity were not satisfied only by slight architectonic modifications on theater buildings. Two directions were followed in search of a real popular theatre that could meet the working-class massively. First, architecture: building new venues, mainly under the influence of Greek theaters but also following the layout of Elizabethan and Spanish Baroque Theaters —as Le Théâtre du Vieux-Colombier in Paris, opened in 1913. The Großes Schauspielhaus, formerly the Circus Schumann, re-opened in Berlin in 1919 refurbished by Hans Poelzig with up to 3500 seats. Managed by Max Reinhardt, the building, in which curtain and proscenium arch were supressed, had a vaste thrust stage surrended in three sides by the audience. Reinhardt’s intention was to gain intimacy, the most close connection among actors and audience the best, whether in large or small halls, as in the Kammerspiele, opened in 1912 as a contiguous venue with the Deutsches Theater in Berlin (Styan, 1982, p. 110). The intention of bringing art to the people and the influence of ancient Greek theatre found also a notable exemplification in other Berlin’s venue: the Volksbühne (People’s Theater), which had its antecesor in an audience organization, the Freie Volksbühne (1890-1895) and later the Neue Freie Volksbühne (1896-1908). The Total Theater is one among the projects that, albeit not realized, has been more influential. The large and multifunctional venue as was signed by Gropius’ studio in 1927 following the requirements by Piscator —who ruled the Volksbühne since 1924— combines working-class accessibility and complex mechanical scenery (Cole, 1963).

div.p: Collectivization of the audience was a heterogeneous movement including disconected tendences that can only be grouped as a meaningfull movement to reinforce the prevalence of the audience in opposition to the self-sufficiency of the plays. As Fuchs was commited with an espiritual symbolism around a völkisch (populist) communion that tended to fascism and Reinhardt pretended a democratic national theatre recognizing the benefits of liberalism, the Volksbühne movement was commited with the socialist empowerment of the working class. Moreover, what was really being highlighted was the relation between the audience and the show: the pragmatics.

Second, and more effective: to leave theater buildings. Open-air performances, that enabled festive experiences and even more massive audiences, were practiced in Germany by Reinhardt and in France, under his influence, by Firmin Gémier and Jacques Copeau (Baron, 2008), but they were a common practice in Russia during the early years after the 1917 Revolution. The reaction was not only in the realm of aesthetics against painted decorative canvases, it was about a progress from painting stage to architecture —which enabled a new organic tridimensional environment for the action as El Lissitzki, Russian architect co-founder of constructivism pointed out in 1922 An attempt was made to transfer the theater from its closed space out into the street. In Pertersburg and other towns the architectural features of the town were supplemented by means of specially erected buildings and used for the magnificent staging of open-air plays, which were attended by thousands upon thousands of people. (cit. in Drain, 1995, p. 40-42) ; furthermore the reaction was triggered against classist habits of distinction, against exclusive access to culture, against fancy protocols of the bourgeoisie and aristocracy. Massive irrational and orgiastic feeling of communion were pretended to reinforce collective structures of belonging, from racial nationalism to proletarian class stratum. In adittion to open-air staging, previously cited obstacles for a real popular meeting were to be surpassed by vanguard practicioners with the recovery and recognition of ancient and inconsiderate theatrical forms such as travelling caravans, medieval board floors, cabaret and circus. Notwithstanding that, leaving theatres was not only a tendence trying to popularize pragmatics: there it was a conscious need of reacting against the model of representation for which theaters were conceived.

Regardless of craftsmanship and protocol, autonomy was initiated but not achieved with the emergence of a first generation of directors whose poetics were engaged with the renewal of the means of naturalist theatre. As quoted above, the autonomy was achieved with the groundbreaking independence of theatre from literature. Servility was overcame during the firs decade of the 20th Century by revolutionary positions embraced by creators as Gordon Craig and Adolphe Appia, visionaries and instigators of anti-realistic poetics that worship Wagnerianism (lighting, space, color, music and specially movement) to the detriment of naturalism (psychological and veracious drama). At the heart of their claims for autonomy it beat an organic conception of grammar that lays on the dynamic articulation of bodyness in space‑time as opposite to any virtuoso transliteration of drama. To serve the field of cinema as an example, autonomy was not achieved only by the invention of the techniques by Auguste and Louis Lumière, neither by the diffusion of the business by Thomas Edison, furthermore it was necessary the former, the later plus the development of an own language by pioneers as Serguéi Eisenstein and D. W. Griffith. Beyond anecdotal, the example brings a closer understanding among the linguistics of both time-based communicative mediis. As Adolphe Appia realized, the grammar of the scene resides on what motion-picture directors called montage or, in his words, on composition as the rhythmic structuring of both space and time.Scenic composition, whose principles are supposed to have no similitude with natural live, is articulated around the first and foremost indispensable element that governs proportions on the scene, the living body of the actor.

cit.quote: Le corps, vivant et mobile, de l’acteur, est le représentant du mouvement dans l’espace. Son rôle est donc capital. Sans texte (avec ou sans musique), l’art dramatique cesse d’exister; l’acteur est le porteur du texte; sans mouvement, les autres arts ne peuvent pas prendre de part à l’action. D’une main, l’acteur s’empare du texte, de l’autre il tient, en un faisceau, les arts de l’espace, puis il réunit, irrésistiblement, ses deux mains et crée, par le mouvement, l’œuvre d’art intégral. Le corps vivant est ainsi le créateur de cet art, et détient le secret des relations hiérarchiques qui en unissent les divers facteurs, puisqu’il est à leur tête. C’est du corps, plastique et vivant, que nous devons partir pour revenir à chacun de nos arts et déterminer leur place dans l’art dramatique.

note.quote: El cuerpo, viviente y móvil, del actor, es el representante del movimiento en el espacio. Su cometido es capital. Sin texto (con o sin música) el arte dramático deja de existir; el actor es el portador del texto; sin movimiento, las otras artes no pueden tomar parte de la acción. Con una mano el actor se apropia del texto, con la otra engloba, como en un haz, las artes del espacio, después reúne, irresistiblemente, sus dos manos y crea, por el movimiento, la obra de arte integral. El cuerpo viviente es así el creador de este arte, y conserva el secreto de las relaciones jerárquicas que aúnan las diversas facturas, pues las encabeza. Es en el cuerpo, plástico y viviente, que encontramos nuestro punto de partida para explorar cada una de muestras artes y determinar su lugar en el arte dramático

div.p: Concerning the prevalence of bodyness it is certain the loyal closeness among theatre and the arts of the movement, both music and dance, in their achievement of high art consideration. Appia used to collaborate with Émile Jaques-Dalcroze, composer and developer of the eurhythmics —pedagogical method to educate the body as a musical instrument— and Gordon Craig held a passionate relationship with Isadora Duncan, acclaimed dancer and pedagogue committed with naturalist movement in self-expression —as opposite to rigid ballet techniques.

figure.head: Isadora Duncan #29 by Abraham Walkowitz circa 1915
figure.figDesc: Watercolor and ink over graphite on off-white, medium-weight, moderately textured laid paper
Brooklyn Museum. Accession Number: 39.174. Public Domain

div.p: Movement emerged not only as the key linguistic substance into the autonomous field of art; moreover, since the expressive nature of bodyness was split from ballet discipline, as movement was systematized by the pioneers of modern dance rejecting artificiality, a new realm not necessarily connected with artistic production arose. From 1913’s and onward Rudolf Laban started to develop his own methods, which were seminal influence in the development of modern dance. His pedagogy, resulted of a mixture of gymnastics and philosophies, highlighted free body expression and space geometry. A distinction between movement applied to professional exhibition and movement by itself began to be discerned. Foundations of Laban’s philosophy were acquitted, among other heterogeneous influences, from Dalcroze (Hodgson, 2001, pp. 68-71). Emphasis was placed into connecting inner creativity and external expression as a whole body activity, as matter of human development both for individuals —as Dalcroze early commenced— and for groups —as it was pointed out by Laban.

cit.quote: Therefore, mastery of movement is not only of value to the stage artist, but to everyone, since we are all concerned whether consciously or subconsciously, with perception and expression. The person who has learned to relate himself to Space, and has physical mastery of this, has Attention. The person who has mastery of his relation to Weight factor of effort has Intention, and he has Decision when he is adjusted time to Time.

div.p: In accordance with the conception by Isadora Duncan, in turn mystically inspired on ancient Greek, harmony became the goal for body training. Harmony was the foundation that connected dance with physical education and therapy, domains where movement requires neither audience nor any kind of external witness. Underlying every acting method from Stanislavski’s to Michael Chekhov’s, every dance pedagogy from Duncan’s to Laban’s, there it was at the beginning of the 20th Century a common recall of spirituality influenced by Western (Schopenhauer’s reading of Kant) and Eastern (Yoga, Buddhism, Sufism) philosophies. An esoteric ontology understanding human being in connection with cosmic rhythms —so close to the spatial geometry by Laban— was brought into physical methods including movement, elocution and sound by Rudolf Steiner starting in 1912; Eurythmy was applied into performance, therapy and education —through Waldorf schooling. Evermore, Anthroposophy became a noteworthy influence throughout Europe during the childbirth of modern art in literature, theatre and dance (Andrei Bely,Michael Chekhov, Rudolf Laban e.g.) Such influence was also remarkable in the advent of the renovating vanguards from 1950’s onward. Nevertheless, the influence from Steiner was not the unique that recalled the need of transcendence into modern dance. George Gurdjieff also considered movement in his series of sacred dances and transcendental geometry in the reveling of the enneagram.

Aside of the above mentioned expressive paths to conciliate body and spirit, other somatic educational methods as those from Frederick Matthias Alexander,Joseph Pilates and Moshé Feldenkrais were systematized during the first quarter of the 20th Century. Nowadays all of them are widley accepted for body training whether in theatre, dance or music, and also practiced outside the field for overall well-being. And if movement and body training could make sense for practicioners outside any showing environment, if inner communication, self-perception and fitness are valious for ordinary people to recovery harmony, so drama could. (Levy-Moreno, psicodrama)

figure.head: Oskar Schlemmer. Drawings of Tänzermensch (Man as dance) circa 1921
figure.figDesc: Public Domain

div.p: While theatre remained subsumed by literature, acting techniques persisted linked to declamation. In literary theatre words by themselves are supposed to have the privilege of reaching the highest artistic heights in voice of the greatest actors. In bourgeoisie drama, speeches are addressed to cause on audience emotional empathy and psychological projection. Naturalism refined mimetic capacities thanks to the modernization of staging techniques (up-dating painted backdrops and footlights), but a real shift was only achieved through the systematization of acting techniques. Even to stage naturalistic drama, considered as literature, directors started to demand actors organic coherence among presence and speech. It is well known how Stanislavski started to develop his system from the years of the Moscow Art Theatre (1897-1922) completing professional specialization methods in pro of comedians’ authenticity and verisimilitude, virtues recognized since the Enlightenment and claimed by Diderot in France or Lessing in Germany (Sanchez, 2001). Stanislavski emphasized on an organic physical involvement to exceed what it is being said in the benefit of what is really happening. His methodological research leaded to roles being recognized for their action. Nevertheless, as in the way Anton Chekhov conceived his dramas, not all what is happening is being said, neither, as symbolism had reminded, all what exists endures visible.

cit.quote: Scenic action is the movement from the soul to the body, from the center to the periphery, from the internal to the external, from the thing an actor feels to its physical form. External action on the stage when not inspired, not justified, not called forth by inner activity, is entertainment only for the eyes and the ears, it does not penetrate the heart, it has no significance in the life of a human spirit on a role.

It is quite natural that with the acting methods which have prevailed up to now, the ‘inspirational’ method and the method of ‘authentic emotions’ (essentially they are one and the same, differing only in their means of realization: the first employs narcotic stimulation, the second — hypnosis), the actor has always been so overwhelmed by his emotions that he has been unable to answer either for his movements or for his voice. He has had no control over himself and hence been in no state to ensure success or failure. Only a few exceptionally great actors have succeeded instinctively in finding the correct method, that is, the method of building the role not from inside outwards, but viceversa. By approaching their role from the outside, they succeeded in developing stupendous technical mastery.

div.p:
In despite of the divergence of opinion on the direction that the actor should traverse to play a roleThis discrepancy, that we may summarize as Do we feel as we behave or do we behave as we feel?, was held in the early twenties, years during which Stanislavski gathered all the materials for his later systematized trilogy. Meyerhold’s quotation is extracted from a 1922 lecture entitled The Actor of the Future and Biomechanics. , Stanislavski agreed with Meyerhold in the necessity of bringing into theatre both forces on human creativity that German Romanticism had disclosed throughout Europe:
Einbildungskraft (imagination),the individual creativeness that actors should deploy to build characters, and
Phantasie (fantasy),the sensory attitude by which attendees merge themselves into the existence of what is performed. So actors’ imagination requests audience’s fantasy to fulfill the magic emergence of an artistic reality capable of touching human soul. While Stanislavski was clearly concerned with promoting actors’ imagination (the direction that goes from the internal to the external) Meyerhold was more interested in stimulating audience’s fantasy (the direction that goes from inside outwards). Imagination is adopted by Michael Chekhov, one among the most outstanding Stanislavski’s students, as the essential point of his acting methods. Under the psycho-physical influence of Rudolf Steiner, Chekhov recognizes the higher ego as the subject’s creative power spring source. Imagination can connect the actor with this trans‑subjective source and can invigorate physical transformations to embody the role thought what he calls psychologically gestures (Chekhov, 2005). Another among Stanislavski’s latest students, Stella Adller, received a notable direct influence on imagination and, after their workout 1934, she started to develop her pedagogy in disagreement wit Lee Strasberg’s lecture on Stanislavski. Instead of insisting on actor’s inner psychology, Adler emphasizes on imagination as a capacity to reconstruct the character from the external circumstances.

cit.quote: A partir de ahora tu trabajo te conducirá a vivir imaginariamente. Verás y actuarás en circunstancias imaginarias. Esto no resturá difícil si aceptas que todo lo que imaginas es verídico. El trabajo del actor consiste en despojar a la ficción de la propia ficción

div.p: Once the autonomy of the field was reached and directors also climbed to the privileged heights of Mount Parnassus, actors were convened not by their personal genius but as mere expressive support for the director’s proposals. Systemic approaches to the actors’ education and training, as those encouraged by pioneers as Stanislavski and Meyerhold, supposed a challenge to performers’ start temperament. But the emergence of an autonomous art did not represent a direct switch in the start system from actors to directors. As it has been mentioned above, the search (or the recovery) of a popular theater was one among the modern tendencies that rouse up against the statu quo praising individualistic genius. As this trend towards collectivization promoted architectonic changes focusing on reception, it also came to emphasize in creation as a collective enterprise. Individual creative skills were put in the perspective of the collective (school, company, troupe or community). If Stanislavski’s Moscow Art Theater represented and alternative to the actors’ leaded theaters in Petersbourg —as was the case of the actress Vera Komissarzhevskaya After Stanislavski decided to close the Theatre-Studio, Komissarzhevskaya called Meyerhold to work with her in Petersburgo, but their relation lasted only until 1907—,Meyerhold’s approach, that was first attempt in the Theater-Studio on Povarskaya Street during the year of the frustrated 1905 Revolution, is recognized as one among the first influences to collective theatrical experiences in the twentieth century (Syssoyeva & Proudfit, 2013). A decade later, between 1924 and 1929, one of the first modern collective communities known as Les Copiaus gathered together around Jacques Copeau, founder of the Théâtre du Vieux-Colombier, and the actor and actor’s trainer Charles Dullin. Physical training including improvisation and commedia dell’arte led Meyerhold and Copeau to empower performer’s generative capabilities into the mise en scène.

figure.head: Members of the Theatre-Studio on Povarskaya Street, 1905
figure.figDesc: Vsevolod Meyerhold, second on the left on the back row
Wikimedia. Public Domain

figure.head: Les Copiaus, 1913
figure.figDesc: Dullin and Copeau, first and second on the left
Le théâtre du Vieux-Colombier

div.p:
Either in addition to cultivating an abarcative understanding of performer’s training and a collective sens of responsibility for productive tasks, Meyerhold and Copeau’s communitarism was commit with a social envision of society pretending, at the same time, to serve as an example from the inside out. But another model of communitarism was possible, one as much devoted to physical discipline as to officiating the sacred. In 1959 Jerzy Grotowski founded the Teatr Laboratorium inheriting largely the experience of Teatru Reduta (1919-1939), founded by Juliusz Osterwa, and specifically succeeding to the image of the artist-collective in retreat from the world, in singular devotion to theatre as a kind of semisecular religion (Syssoyeva & Proudfit, 2013, p. 18)
Syssoyeva also includes Copeau into this monastic tradition, but we prefer to make a distinction regarding Copeau’s political engagement represented in his commitment with Le théâtre populaire. In contrast with Copeau’s communitarism, focused to productive and practical organization of the group, Reduta’s tradition advocates strictly to a religious isolation not pretending social but inner transformations.. This devoted conception of performer entrusted to discipline as a way of living was continued, since 1964, by Grotowskis’s pupil Eugenio Barba in his Odin Teatret, which celebrates in 2014 its 50th aniversary. The aforesaid notwithstanding, most radical postures were commited with surpassing, in the realm of production, the romantic notion of individual singularity and with exemplifying, in the realm of reception, horizontal and equalitarian organization, specially after the Protests of 1968. Political responsability and collective playwriting as envisioned by Piscator held sway over The Living Theatre in the USA, the Théâtre du Soleil in France or the Teatro Experimental de Cali and La Candelaria in Colombia e.g.

Despite of this movements towards collective creativity, the starsystem remained predominant: Vera Komissarzhevskaya, Eleonora Duse,Sarah Bernhardt… are some among the names that may exemplify the individualistic mainstream. In opposition, individualism was perceived by avant-garde artists as the negative counterpart of modern subjectivity, as a limit to be overpassed thought either an external (political) or internal (ontological) way.

cit.quote: El aislamiento del artista actual es un hecho. Nuestra época carece de una idea grande y común, de una religión. La pretensión de los artistas consiste en hacerla resurgir y el camino que conduce hasta ella se advierte en primer lugar en el subjetivismo absoluto de las conciencias individuales.

div.p: As stated by Walter Gropius in the Manifesto of the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, isolation can only be salvaged by the purposeful and cooperative endeavors of all artisans, including architecture and sculpture and painting (1923). The Bauhaus’ Bühnenwerkstatt (Stage workshop), directed first by Lothar Schreyer (1921-1923) and later by Oskar Schlemmer (1923-1929), was an experimental environment where the body in its physical parameters (statics, dynamics and equilibrium) became the center pillar of stage composition. Literature based theater and traditional ballet were completely overcame and merged into a modern collaborative conjunction of craftsmanship around a non-psychological centrality of bodyness. Nevertheless, the complete cancellation of literature supposed just the furthest among the innovating positions of modern staging towards all-embracing art unity. It seems necessary to solve an apparent contradiction between the emergence of an autonomous field and the defending of the principle of total art convergence, principle flexible indeed which wanders around since Wagner’s thesis, and which concerns aesthetics —ambition to borderlessness—, politics —aspiration to a better collective future— and even metaphysics —artwork of everything— (Finger & Follett, 2011, pp. 3, 25). The concept of Gesamtkunstwerk (total work of art) is antithetical with the understanding of isolated disciplines and autonomous functioning, but when the autonomy of performing arts as a field is referred, a common communicative process concerning bodyness, time and space is pointed out. This autonomous domain was perceived as such once that theater, dance and music were distinguished together in their pragmatical nature; the essence of the scenic work of art lays on the process, not in the object (literary script, composition or choreography) anymore. Since Bayreuth’s Festival the scene was known to work as a matrix in which the merging of historically separated disciplines can become into and organic aesthetic reality. Autonomous scenic art disposes of every linguistic substance to converge into an unified living discourse. The paradigmatic object of the autonomous art of the scene was named as Bühnenkomposition (scenic composition) by Wassily Kandinsky (1911) under the influence of Russian constructivism, or as Bühnenkunstwerk by Lothar Schreyer (1916) out of the expresionist sphere.

The convergence of the arts of the stage was a movement sustained both by a technical collaboration of artisans concerned with the form and, at the same time, not inconsistently although separately, by a philosophical claim of the symbol and its endowments on giving access to a metaphysical dimension. Symbolism derives from the principle of synesthesia —a unity of sensual experience—, and even more from the theological conception of correspondences according to which every aspect on this material dimension has its analogous on the spiritual one. We can easily make the link between the latter mystic conception by Emanuel Swedenborg and the symbolic nature of human world that has been canonized throughout Charles Baudelaire’s Correspondances (1857). Symbolism in its widest sense should be explained as a general movement that, since the second half of the nineteenth century, arose in opposition to the materialistic understanding of society and, consequently, to the banal depicting of reality. Not only scenic arts but all European cultural fields were in the claim of l’art pour l’art . Philosophical aesthetics rooted in Kant’s judgment of taste as an autonomous via, not dependent on moral or cognitive judgments, recognized a metaphysical nature of art that is by itself, detached from beauty or any ethical value. Empowered by the heuristic capabilities of the symbol, aesthetic discourse brings the possibility of direct experiencing transcendence: no need of any resemblance with natural world, no need of canonical representation, no need of ethical neither political commitment. Symbolism as a neo-kantian wave broke against the prevailing art heir of the Enlightenment committed with edifying and entertaining society. It is widely accepted that symbolism confronted naturalism, but this assertion dismisses its deep philosophical position regarding representation. The idealistic search of transcendence cannot avoid forms, evermore it traces a perceptual ontology. Meta-aesthetics does not concern a programmatic style of representation nor the way the forms are but the resonances that forms can produce. It may result obvious how the insignificance of the style of representation in accessing spirituality gave rise to abstract forms, but it has not been so indicated how figurative forms can also bring access to transcendence. This is the via Stanislavski called spiritual naturalism in which he synthesized idealism, orientalism into a systemic scientific approach to acting techniques. In the same way, Bauhaus, which was concerned by pure forms and its mechanics, did not skipped spirituality, on the contrary, it was so consciously influenced by Kandinsky’s Über das Geistige in der Kunst (1911). In 1922, Walter Gropius, introducing the stage workshop grounded:

cit.quote: We are also working on the development of the stage. To purify and renew today’s stage, which, it seems, has lost its intimate ties to the world of human feelings, is a task for those who, starting from a common point, are devotedly working to accomplish a fundamental clarification of the all-embracing problem of the stage, both in theory and in practice, unaffected by personal considerations and free of the limitations of the commercial theater. In its origin the stage derives from an ardent religious desire of the human soul (theater=show for the gods). It serves, then, to manifest a transcendental idea. The power of its effect on the soul of the spectator and auditor is therefore dependent on the success of the transformation of the idea into (visually and acoustically) perceivable space.

div.p: It is true that symbolism supposed a reacting force against the hegemonic theatre leaded by naturalism, the vaudeville and the classical repertoire. In Paris, as an alternative to Antoine’s Théâtre Libre,Paul Fort founded the Théâtre d’Art in 1890, project continued since 1893 by Lugné-Poe in the Théâtre de l’Œuvre —where Alfred Jarry premiered Ubu Roi in 1896. Even being theatre subsumed under literature, even Maurice Maeterlinck —the most successful playwright of the time— not considering theatre capable of reaching the heights of the poem, symbolism represented a new position that should not be thought only against the precise depicting of contemporary life. The confrontation between objectivism and subjetivism —the skeptic production of modern knowledge— may be considered as constituent essence of modernity since Descartes. We totally agree with György Lukács that when analyzing the dichotomy naturalism vs. anti-naturalism, it is ideology not the way art forms look like which should be focused.

cit.quote: We shall concentrate on the underlying ideological basis of these trends […] What must be avoided at all cost is the approach generally adopted by bourgeois-modernist critics themselves: that exaggerated concern with formal criteria, with questions of style and literary technique […] We are presented with a false polarization which, exaggerating the importance of stylistic differences, conceals the opposing principles actually underlying and determining contrasting styles.

div.p: Although demands being art for art’s shake, Marxist criticism came to remain that there is no aesthetic production detached from ideology. Traditional art depicting physical reality and modern art accessing spiritual dimension are considered both bourgeoisie poetics standing up for a common ontology that concerns the subject as a cognitive being who needs the world to be objectified, represented to be apprehended. Naturalism and symbolism can therefore be read as a single range within its limits the subject becomes blurred because of a lack or an excess of itself: realism pretends as if there were a reality independent of the cognitive subject, idealism pretends as if there were nothing outside the subject’s cognition. But Marxist criticism is not concerned with philosophical lucubrations by themselves but with their causes and consequences, and it asks after the intentions veiled under aesthetics in relation with the maintenance or the subversion of a materialistic and unequal status quo (hegemony). Therefore, it was not symbolism by itself, nor the dialog on representation held with naturalism concerning aesthetics, but the criticism towards the system which enabled consciously opposing postures concerning politics. Such postures led to a destructive attitude towards the past and, as consequence, towards an Utopian envision of the future. Art and culture became weapons for the rupture with established forms representing established values.

The massive spread of the Filippo Tomasso Marinetti’s manifesto in 1909 thorough several international newsletters outstanding Le Figaro was soon followed, among other actions, by serate, or theatrical evenings which involved declaiming poetry, reading manifestos, burning the Austrian flag, and generally inciting the audience into riot (Poggi, 2009, p. 1-2). Conventional theatricality including music and dance was also taken into account from a deconstructive approach both performing (e.g. Francesco Cangiullo,Luigi Russolo) and spreading manifesti (From the variety theatre in 1913, Manifesto of Dynamic and Synoptic Declamation in 1914, Teatro futurista sintetico in 1915, Manifesto of the Futurist Dance, in 1917).

cit.quote: È STUPIDO non ribellarsi al pregiudizio della teatralità quando la vita stessa (la quale è costituita da azioni injinitamente più impaccia‑te, più regolate e più prevedibili di quelle che si svolgono nel campo dell’arte) è in massima parte antiteatrale e offre anche in questa sua parte innumerevoli possibilità sceniche. TUTTO È TEATRALE QUANDO HA VALORE.

div.p: In addition to massively addressing the need of abrogating tradition, to a defiant attitude toward audience, Italian futurism stands out for pioneering sociocultural actionism blurring the boundaries between live and art and emphasizing performance in detriment of the intrinsic value of plays.

Futurism in Russia was assumed over an own earlier experimental tradition envisioning anti-realism, grotesque, meta-theatrality, puppets, Spanish medieval theater and commedia dell’arte. Nikolai Evreinov embodied all previous stated tendencies and his conception on theatricality —first published in Apology for Theatricality (1908) recognizing life over the stage— became so influential for the earliest Russian avant-gardist. Heir of that meaningful experimental tradition and of an own metaphysical symbolism, futurism in Russia was not a cohesive movement as was it was in Italy and instead of being devoted to anti-art actionism, creators as Ilia Zdanevich,Velimir Khlebnikov and Aleksei Kruchenykh encounter innovative forms (aleatority, automatic writing, absurd) anticipating dadaism and surrealism in their provocative confrontation with the rationalist construct of the bourgeoisie’s world. Vladimir Mayakovsky became the speaker of the movement publishing the manifest A Slap in the Face of Public Taste in 1912. After the October Revolution cubo-futurism diverted to constructivism by moving from formalist research to a pure materialist conception of theater devoted to productive reasons and social goals. Soon constructivist assumptions against autonomous art were adopted by some among the most experimental theater practitioners, including Mayakovsky, Meyerhold and Sergei Eisenstein, who opted to promote agitation and propaganda on behalf of the Prolekult, organization founded and leaded by Anatoly Lunacharsky. During the firs decade after the Revolution, theater was considered as a privileged domain for the meeting of people and ideas, for the self-education, and so received a great impulse for promoting amateurism in clubs as in any other possible venue all along the country (Mally, 2000). In addition to requesting people’s public role both as practitioners and audience, experimentality linked to utilitarianism was also promoted. Rejecting naturalism, symbolism and even the recognition of art, constructivist theaterThe works by Meyerhold leading working groups together with the stage constructors Varvara Stepanova and Liubov Popova during the period 1922-1924 included Magnanimous Cuckold, The Death of Tarelkin and Earth in Turmoil (Barris, 2013, p. 68) renounced the subject for the object: text, acting, scenography, lighting (including cinema projections) merged not in the way total artwork’s theory postulated —organically— but in the way different components conform a machine as result of a collaborative assembly and, with more importance, as result of a new syntax —montage— capable of articulating discourse without ever needing the structuring categories from the classic theory of drama. But after Trotsky’s fall, since 1928 onward, Stalin’s new orthodoxy subsumed art under dogmatism, which canceled further developments out. Almost all artist were went into exile, deported or killed under successive purges (Berlin, 2000). Nevertheless, materialistic postures supposed a fundamental influence for the Bauhaus and for the German political theater.

Erwin Piscator resumed in Germany the proletarian political theater giving continuity to the Bolshevist’s promotion of amateurism. From 1920 to 1921, before his Volksbühe phase, Piscator promoted the Proletarisches Theater , a working-class troupe touring halls and meeting rooms. As mettuer en scène Piscator’s aesthetics held a difficult equilibrium in the limits of contradiction trying to bring ideological materialism through the means of total theater (huge productions, mechanized stage, cinema projections…) Piscator was aware of criticism on this unlikely balance (Piscator, 1980) but he did not renounce to artistic pretensions understanding that techniques were just fair procedures for the message addressing the audience, that ideology does not require unveiling the apparatus nor breaking the illusio, that the most emotionally touched the audience can result the most profound the rational reflection can be taken. Emphasis, therefore, is placed on dramaturgy, on the internal structure of drama; the style of representation does not implicates falseness by itself, even more, stage’s resources in an industrialized age are useful means for the director to connect massive audiences. Piscator postulated epic drama as the narrative of a political hero facing society contrary to the autonomous one that faces destiny, god, nature or either his own passions (Piscator, 1980, pp. 41-42). In addition, being influenced by montage theories from Lev Kuleshov,Dziga Vertov and Vsevolod Pudovkin as by the discursive structure of radio and newsletters, epic form plunges into crisis the linearity of Aristotelian drama replacing the cause-and-effect relationship of events by mere juxtaposition.

Together with collective creation, documentary theater is one among the tendencies that most meaningfully represent dynamism within the field —literary drama and so writer’s loss of central prominence, blurring of precise boundaries between live and stage and, consequently, politicization of performance. Piscator premiered in 1925 in the Großes Schauspielhaus In Spite of everything, a play collectively envisioned as a montage of authentic speeches, essays, newspaper cuttings, appeals, pamphlets, photographs, and film of the War and the Revolution, of historical persons and scenes (Piscator, 1980, p. 94). Three main precedents may be pointed out in Piscator’s development of documentary playwriting: Karl Kraus, photomontage, and living newspaper. Karl Kraus, writer and journalist, developed a satiric quotation style based on détournement. He himself used to perform, not acting but reading, in Vienna and throughout Europe, excerpts of his more than six hundred pages collage drama about the World War I Die letzten Tage der Menschheit (The Last Days of Mankind) (1919) (Youker, 2012). Photomontage techniques from Dadaists had enabled the reword of reality through the sources of the industrialized mass media. Berliner branch (Hausmann, Höch,Grosz, and Heartfield) emphasized on the virtues the technique owns for political criticism and parody. Living Newspaper became popular after the Bolshevik Revolution evolving from a public reading of the news, due to the high level of illiteracy, to a more elaborated theatrical discourse. The National Institute of Journalist in Moscow founded a first dedicated troupe in 1923, The Blue Blouse.Living Newspaper flourished in the United States during the 1930s thanks to the Federal Theatre Project (Dawson, 1999, p. 20).

Documentary drama, including all its sub-genres from verbatim to newspaper theater, specially since its expansion during 1960’s, made the empowering of the subaltern possible. In this case stronger tensions arose with the outside than within the field: documentary theater does not only displace authorship from the center of gravity, it does not only displace literature, but also it exemplifies an alternative to mass media concerning the public representation of marginalized collectives, of those minor histories excluded or silenced. At the same time it has been a privileged way to enrich theatre-in-education. Empowering communities, making people aware of the materialistic conditions that trample their lives, giving instruments for the critic analysis of their reality as a way for social change are political theater’s aims since the first revolutionary experiences to the Theatre of the Oppressed, a set of structured techniques elaborated by Augusto Boal in Brazil during the 1960’s that had spread theatre for social change all over the world.

Didactics as epic and factual drama, trends that Piscator opened, were followed by Bertolt Brecht expanding political theater. Brecht introduced a key concept that differed from Piscator and reconnected back with constructivism poetics: the display must be evidently demonstrated. Brecht pretended drama to rationally burden problems with the audience and so, as such intention required avoiding identification, he encouraged the Verfremdungseffekt (estrangement-effect) by which audience stays emotionally away from what is represented. Brecht’s methods breaking drama’s linearity pretended making performance’s situation obvious. Meta-theatricality corresponds to the showing of of the representation, a logic that enables criticism wrapping actors and audience in their historical time.

But even more transcendental than the Marxist alternative assumed by Piscator and Brecht, political theater made evident that theater is political per se, that hegemonic ideology tends to become transparent, that hegemonic ideology prefers de‑politicisation than political confrontation to remain hegemonic. After the 1960’s, with the rise of identity movements, politics became ubiquitous in all theatre criticism, and such an excess led to the need of a methodological shift: from focusing the political in theatre and performance to detecting the theatrical and performative in politics (Kershaw, 1997). The rites both of the hegemonic power as of the resistance can be analyzed as performance. The abrogation of the distinction among elite and popular culture, the dissolution of the limits between live and art that advocate futurists, that Artaud dreamed, arts’s demystification as Dada voiced, was committed in the occupation of the Parisian Théâtre de l’Odéon in May 1968.

If the most revolutionary displacement toward autonomy was related with the twist of Aristotelian drama, its abrogation motivated the expansion of the field. If Symbolism skipped physical mimesis, if Futurism rejected art escaping from its rules, Dada broke the rules pretending to elevate the breaking to the category of art in a way that Carl Jung described as schizophrenic It’s too idiotic to be schizophrenic cit. in Melzer, 1994, p. 54 . At the height of World War I, in 1916, Cabaret Voltaire opened its door in Zurich. In its soirées (nights) Hugo Ball,Emmy Hennings,Tristan Tzara, Marcel Janco and Hans Arp (among others exiles) came together with the audience celebrating absurd and pacifistic events that included masquerade, phonetic poems, cubist dance, and all kind of spontaneous and hilarious acts. Dada took up again from Futurism, among other influences, the intention of interweaving with mass media, but drove such intention further; moreover than the mere disseminating of their foundations, Dada appropriated advertisement and commercial products from everyday life subverting their meaning.Walter Benjamin already noticed in 1936 that the revolutionary strength of Dadaism consisted in testing art for its authenticity. (Benjamin, 2008, p. 86). From photomontage to readymades everything can become Art. And if everything can become art, everyone can perform or, as was voiced in a poster of the Berlin Dada Fair (1920) Everyone can Dada. It is indeed ironic that Dada, which renounced to aesthetics, drama, scenic techniques and professionalism, represents the largest stretching of field’ boundaries. Dada’s utmost importance concerning performing arts lays in its consequences: it would result hard not to trace an influence line rooting every vanguard since 1030’s (Situationism, Fluxus, Happening, Performance Art, Body Art, Minimalism, Pop Art, Video Art) back to Dada and Futurism. Furthermore, every artistic expression coming after the rules being ripped by sacrilegious vanguards, even conservative art, generates its social meaning (aesthetic and political) in an unstable social context of reception. Dada may represent the the shift from theatre to performance as theatre, searching for the possibilities of theatre, returned to its origins in the actor as performer. (Melzer, 1984, p. 33) And returning to its mythical origin, to the pre‑aesthetic spirit of the dithyrambic chorus, performance arises as an artistic attitude that blurring boundaries challenges both everyday’s life and stage craftsmanship. Taking the limit to paroxysm we may say that theater becomes autonomous when it stops depending on theatricality. Such an argument may not result rather odd precisely because far from canceling modernity, crisis, negation and radical critique —as brought by Futurism, Dadaism and Surrealism— were consolidating its birthFor the relation between modernity and avant-garde movements see Henri Lefebvre’s Introduction to Modernity: Twelve Preludes, September 1959-May 1961 1995, pp. 105-107, 182 .

figure.head: Opening of the 1st International Dada Fair in Berlin, 1913
